title: CST L-Trac 2-Swtch Auxiliary Button Housing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The CST L-Trac trackball is a wonderfully customizable device, thanks to its two auxiliary button ports. I've seen foot-controlled switches designed to work with the CST, but some of us would prefer to have the switch mounted for use by the trackball hand.

I don't know who did it first, but I got the idea from reddit user ripster55 to use Cherry MX-style keyboard switches for my aux buttons, as seen here: http://imgur.com/a/bhicE

I designed this housing to fit the curves of the CST L-Trac and put the switch in easy reach of the right-hand thumb. This was my third iteration, and allows for two switches to be installed, including enlarged wiring ports for doubling up the wiring. It also includes some almost-certainly-unnecessary internal bracing. It didn't feel at all springy or flexy without it, but I tend to enjoy overbuilding, so there it is.

Notes:

I used zigzag infil, and it was effortless to remove. I recommend printing this with the trackball-side down for long print lines, and a nicely-finished outer edge. Unfortunately, this direction defaults in some support material in the outer edge of the switch inset. It doesn't seem to have affected the fit at all, though.

The CST does not include any mounting options. You'll need to either glue this to the side of the trackball, or some up with your own ingenious mounting strategy. I have mounted mine with silicone caulk (the exact same stuff I make for brewing Oogoo). It's holding up well.

description.text:
I made this keychain with the help of the maker from the Vito keychain (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1671726)

I hope you guys like it!

This is a very cheap telesope tracker with the base components cost less than 10$.
It is made for a EQ-5 mount but can probably be adapted to others.
Part list:

  • arduino nano or clone
  • stepper motor type 28BYJ-48 incl driver pcb ULN2003
  • 200mm closed "GT2" belt
  • some sort of power supply (I use a single li-io cell, 3.7V)
  • 3 pushbuttons of any size for fast forward, backward, lunar vs stellar speed
  • printed parts
  • a few screws

I actually drilled a hole into my telescope mount and cut a M4 thread into it to fix the base (see photos). You may want to re-design the base to do this less invasive.
The 16 teeth pulley fits onto the stepper without any screw, the 64 teeth one can be fixed with a screw at the hour-axis drive (see photos). I also used an M4 screw there.

The included little arduino project is made for a 144 teeth main gear as featured on the EQ-5 mount. For other tooth counts, this can be patched.

Electrical connections:
pins 9,10,11,12 from the arduino go to the stepper controller, 5V supply and gnd of both boards are just connected.
I use a single li-io cell (3.7V) and connect it directly to the 5V pins. The complete thing consumes about 180mA so that a 2Ah cell can easily last 10h.
The thing should also run from a power bank via the USB connector. It will take a bit more current then, and you need to mount the arduino board so that the USB socket is reacheable.
Pins 2,3,4 can be connected to some sort of pushbuttons that drag those pins to gnd when pressed (the arduino board features internal pullup-resistors). This toggles lunar vs stellar speed and does fast forward / fast backward. See the ino file for details. On the photos, this is the little 4-lead gray cable. Without any button the stepper just runs in stellar mode. It makes sense to connect the pushbuttons with a cable to avoid vibrations when operating them.

Programming:

  • download arduino
  • install the "timer1" lib via the sketch->lib menu
  • open the tracker.ino file
  • connect the arduino nano (windows may install some drivers)
  • upload the program (you may need to check the hw manager to find the port)

If you mount the whole thing the other way round, or live south from the equator, you need to patch the code to reverse directions. Just replace
if(d==1)
with
if(d!=1)

When connected to USB, the boards are supplied from there (and the stepper will also run). Therefore:

DO NOT connect both battery (especially if it is not 5V but goes to the 5V pin) and USB since this connects the battery voltage directly to the USB 5V pin!!!

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the segments with the linking arms on the bottom.  This allows for the 'reflective' surface to be smoother.  The CAP however needs to be flipped and printed top down due to the geometry.

description.text:
NASA's Space Fabric

Overview

JPL submitted an article on a "4-D" printed fabric that could be used to protect objects in space. I used the images and attempted to create a model as close to the original as possible. I modified the model so that the reflective surface would be printed last (on top). This allows the surface to be smoother and more similar to the model.

My segments are not as small as those in the image from NASA. This is due to the diameter of the linking arms. In the image, the linking arms are probably close to 1 mm. At that diameter, my printer can not print the linking arms accurately.

The attached files are 2 X the size of the NASA segments with a linking arm diameter of 2 mm and top size of 16 x 16 mm. The pitch between the segments is 10 mm. This model scales easily if you have a printer with a better resolution.

Modifications

Combine Assemblies

I've remixed the segments to create a Cap and Base. This allows you to combine assemblies where the final dimensions would be greater then your printer bed allows for. An example of this is the NASA Chainmail Tie.

Hex Chainmail

I remixed the original segment to mate on six sides with a hexagonal pattern. This model has a pitch of 23 mm.

Equilateral Triangle

Per DavidPhillipOster's recomendation I've designed a similar part using an equilateral triangle. I've maintained the design thickness and ratios. This design illustrates well the trade-off between the number of sides and the face density. Parts: triangle_nascha.stl and triangle_hexpat.stl

Parts

  • The segments are 2X_SEGMENT.stl
  • I've uploaded a 3x3 section of the 2X segments as 3x3_ASM.stl
  • The cap and base segments are
    • 2X_CAP.stl
    • 2X_BASE.stl
  • The hexagonal parts are
    • Segment: simnas6_2x_seg.stl
    • Assembly over a 100 x 100 mm area: simnas6_2x_asm.stl
  • Equilateral Triangle
    • Segment: triangle_nascha.stl
    • Assembly: triangle_hexpat.stl

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

I printed the segments with the linking arms on the bottom. This allows for the 'reflective' surface to be smoother. The CAP however needs to be flipped and printed top down due to the geometry.

title: Clearance Remix for Adjustable Robo 3D R1+ Y axis bearing blocks

description.text:
This remix gives additional clearance on the sides of the top carrier so they do not rub against the bottom of the build plate heating element. It moves the side screw mount points down by 3mm.

Also, on my printer at least, the change makes it so you can't over-tighten the top carrier. Just screw it down all the way as tight as you want, and the spacing appears to perfectly match the 8mm smooth rods (due to printer differences, your mileage may vary).

You will need to use the bottom piece from the original

You will need to raise up the idler bearings, stepper pulley and limit switch. To raise the idler posts I simply added another 608zz and removed the lower large washer because it wasn't needed. To raise the limit switch I used some washers to raise it up and also glued a bit of plastic to the lever arm to make it taller. Raising the stepper pulley is easy: just loosen the set-screws, move it up, and then tighten them again.

I am using cheap bearings from Amazon, even though I'm not supposed to :) Because you can't over-tighten the top block, I hope that the cheap bearings will still work in the long-run.

The included .zip file has the openscad files, as well as the top piece from the original.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1373201

It works well and fits well, no screw needed.

It reduces the available build height by about 30mm but I felt that was worth it so I could add better part cooling.

Clamps use m3 screws 4 off, Print 2 of those.

Arms fit the effector using the same mounting screws.

If you do use the same fan duct insulate the hot end from the close proximity of the heat block.

remixed_from.title: Cable chain, perfect fit and rounded edges

title: Wire chain for Sunhokey Prusa i4

description.text:
This cable chain for Sunhokey Prusa i4 based on perfect A.N.Onymous link design:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:666118

There are few changes made in original link design.

  • Link shaft was lengthened a bit for chain to be more solid.
  • Small support bars were added under shaft ends for better print quality. You will need to cut off supports before assembling a chain
  • First 10 of 23 links were adjusted to have stronger bending as print head in right upper position is too close to acrylic frame.

I also created two end links. The first one is glued to the bottom of extruder stepper motor. The last is screwed to the right side of acrylic plate next to the frame. I’ve made a 10x10mm notch from the right side of acrylic plate instead of passing wires through hole so wire chain may be easily detached if needed.

Please use SketchUp sources for adjustments

description.text:
My flatmate really gets off on Kerrygold so for his birthday I made him this "Tactical Kerrygold" which is a Cover for the standard Kerrygold plastic box (I assume it also fits for most other brands of butter) that clips to his belt.

Now he can take his Kerrygold wherever he goes and whenever he needs something buttered he can pull it from his belt, squeeze it on the item to be buttered and snap it back to his hip. A real tactical movement and a real life-improvement!

I must say that this first prototype works remarkably well - I wouldn't have guessed... :O :D

P3Steel & some mods

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer hight

Infill:

20% cubic

Notes:

I sliced with Prusa's Sic3er
printed in PLA
orientation as is

1x KerryPlate
2x KerryClip

Welding clips to plate

After printing this out you stick the clips into the back of the plate and stuff a good line of plastic into the remaining chamfers with a 3D printing pen (excellent welding tool!).

Metal effector designed to fit on a Delta with magnetic ball joints. Ball spacing is 43 mm.
The effector is designed to hold the Aero Titan hot end extruder combo.

Added V2. Modified the frame to make access to the filament leaver a little easier.
Added spacers between the effector and the stepper, so that standard 35 mm M3 screws can be used.
Added a 1 mm gap between the fan and the top mount of the effector, so it is easier to assemble. Use a 1 mm thick washer between the effector and the fan.
Made the post thicker, as it was too flimsy in plastic.

If you are considering this and don't have an extruder yet, can I respectfully request you have a look at the Zesty Nimble first? Same functionality but at a fraction of the weight. The extruder is less than 27 grams.

Originally designed by Jens Risom, who designed the first chair for Knoll, this chair known as the Risom side chair was assigned to me in a CAD class to model in Rhino.
I went and took a few pictures and some measurements of one then made my model. The chair is supposed to have webbing but my skill level wasn't up to it. I think it is my learning curve not the limits of Rhino.

I've made it a thing in progress but the frame is complete, I just need to tackle the webbing.
I have included the source file that allows you to see each part; frame, legs, dowels and bolts and also try your hand at the webbing or some other solution!
It will definitely need to be scaled down to fit on a printer as it is full size but if you have rhino you could extract the measurements and make your own wood one!
I think knowing about bridge feature might be handy but I don't know much about it to be honest.
If you print them you could use paper strips as webbing.

author: rogdodger1

print_settings.Infill:: Solid... so the sucker don't be breaking again!

description.text:
"Heck... The knob on my ***** broke!"

Today the knob on my steamer broke.
I like steamed vegetables.
I hate it when things break, don't you?

I made this.
The old one broke so easily.... I wonder why 'they' designed it that way, so flimsy and easily broken.
It's almost as if 'they' want me to go buy a new one, just because the knob came off.

I shall resist their puny plan.... because I have a 3d printer and Fusion360.

Not only shall I design a better one, and make it in a nicer colour, but I shall make it STRONGER... yes, STRONGER I tell you.... and it shall not fail as your limp effort did fail!
It will LIVE... and succeed, as yours merely crumbled and fell when work was to be done.

It must, by default, fit a 5mm shaft, be secured using a 1mm thick strip of steel that fits in a slot on the timer shaft and be 42mm in diameter.
I think we can do that, no problem.

Haaaahaaaaa! Foiled your plans again...
Take that....

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

Solid... so the sucker don't be breaking again!

1. Resize and/or customize as appropriate.
  2. Print.
  3. Fit.
  4. Use.

Normal human safety precautions should be observed.

Hint. Try not to set your face, or indeed any significant body parts, on fire.

"Necessity is the mother of 3d printing a knob for a kitchen appliance..."
Miss Thomas G. Edison IV (1745-1741)

title: Arduino CO-CO2 Sensor v.2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is the second version of a my previous project, Arduino CO2 Sensor. The most important changes are: the add of an OLED display, the Carbon Monoxide Sensor (toxic gas that derivates from incomplete combustions), the ventilation system and the possibility to record data. I have printed the case in PLA with my Prusa i3 x. The MQ135 (air-quality sensor) is controlled by an Arduino Mega and it is connected with a HC-06 bluetooth module to interact with an Android smartphone (and see the ppm level). A yellow led will switch on when the sensor detects 1000 ppm and a red led will switch on when it detects 1500 ppm.
I have decided to construct this sensor in particular for schools. Infact, I have noticed that the level of attention decreases with a high CO2 level. In my website you can see the CO2 graph that I have recorded in my classroom.
I hope you can find this sensor useful!

P.s. :

title: Moto G5 PLUS protective case Bulk
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This case is designed for the Motorola (Lenovo) Moto G5. It has two cutouts on the back, for the camera bump and for the Motorola logo. On the side, it has a cutout for the volume key buttons and lock button and, on the bottom, it has a cutout for the charging port and the audio jack. If printed properly, it should snap nicely in, like a normal commercial case.

NOTICE: Unlike what you see on the photos, the 3D model has also a cutout on the back for the noise canceling microphone. I noticed the mistake only after printing the first case. I will update the post with new pictures soon.

This is the Bulk version of the following case:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2407569

You can modify it and add your own patterns and designs on the back. Enjoy making and redesigning it and, please share your results:D

UPDATE!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Please note that this case is for the G5 Plus, NOT for the G5. Sorry for my error.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Preferably, print it with soft, flexible materials like ABS, PETG, TPU or BDP (as the one in the pictures). You can also try PLA, but you might break it when trying to squeeze the phone in and out of the case.

Use the mouse-ears model for materials with warping potential. Cut them away with a cutter-knife after you remove the print from the build platform.

I designed it based on my personal measurements of the Moto G5 and I would estimate an average measurement error of ca. 0.5 mm (on the corner fillets). Still, all the cutouts seem to allign perfectly and it clips really nicely around the phone.

The case is designed to be squeezed over the phone like regular, commercial cases.

Also, a really great advantage is that the phone sits much nicer in the hand and is not as slippery as without the case... so, with this one, you get both prevention and protection;)

description.text:
This is yet another iPhone Dock in MSI Style. I used red 6mm LEDs to light it up. Unfortunally i dont have a Picture of the Installation but i upload one foto from AutoCAD to explain the Installation.
First, i removed the Isolation of the cable and measured out, which cables are powered. Then i soldering an extra cable on it and glue the conector in place. After all is dried, i soldering two 50Ohm resistors (one resistor for 2 LEDs in one Line) and all LEDs together. (See attached wiring diagramm).
At least i glue the bottom piece on the main part and its done :). Optional i put two 3mm holes in the bottom to screw the bottom piece.

Even though I rare use the idler, I always found it is not finger-friendly.

Update #1 (03.11.2017)
I added a cap for the screw heads. Now the idler handling is really easy.

Place the screws to the holes of the printed cap. The holes are designed to fit tight with the screws.
Then place the springs and screw the idler to the extruder body.

description.text:
I wanted to firmly attach my X52 Pro to the arms of my chair, as my desk is elevated too high.
I have also added (a currently untested, but should fit) X55/56 mounting bracket. This requires 4 60mm M4 bolts.

To Print:

  • 2 * Mount
  • 2 * Thread (May need the edge of the thread cutting down to fit in the socket, depending on your printers tolerance).
  • 2 * Socket i (STL is correct for thread STL, the inventor file may have revered thread)
  • 2 * Twist
  • 2 * Twist J ( correct size for joystick )
  • 4 * Washer

Additional Hardware:

  • 4 - 8 65mm * 3.6 mm screws
  • 4 15mm screws
  • Rubber pads (optional)

title: Suzuki-Style Fine-Tuners
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Suzuki-style (somewhat) violin fine-tuners. Allows a small but precise change in a string's pitch. This is important on bowed instruments and those with main tuning pegs held in place by friction alone.

These work okay. The Fusion360 file is here: http://a360.co/2sukYdl

I used 3mm t-slot extrusion cam nuts and bolts to "hook" the strings. This worked well.

Because of the fine details, you will need to set your printer in whatever ways necessary to reproduce these parts accurately. I printed in PETG, and would recommend this material for this item. Finishing can be done with a hot knife, sandpaper, and needle files.

Printer:

Modified Folger Tech Prusa i3 - T-slot Extrusion version

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No
Good for fine-tuning of stringed instruments.
Goal: Shows students a useful application of 3D printing in the music and arts fields. Easy to mass-produce. Very inexpensive.

Basic Materials You'll need an instrument with enough room behind the bridge and in front of the instrument's tailpiece to fit this tuner. You'll need a 3D printer that will print PETG. ABS and PLA may work, but I have not tried those with this part. The only parts not included: the hardware used. I used metric 3mm socket-head-cap-screws and an accompanying cam-nut for aluminum t-slot extrusion. Any bolt that closely fits the hole and any nut that properly "hooks" the string can be used.
Thumbscrews are much better than SHCS for this part. You'll need a quality electric tuner as well.

A small hand hold unit allows you to write a message in the air just by waving. It uses an Arduino NanoV3 to create the message in a simple straightforward way.
Write the message in Excel and define HIGH or LOW per led in the sketch. An example sketch is attached, the heart may need some surgery :-). The message writes continuously.

A 9 volt block cell provides the power.

These brackets will eventually break, and there's no spare parts, since IKEA don't produce this model anymore.
I dismantled the original curtain brackets, and I measured them, and then recreated their shapes in every aspect.

I have added a version 2 of the B-bracket, because while the brackets are similar to the originals, you can experience problems with catching, because the aluminum guidance can tilt a bit, and this is just enough to allow the catchers to pass each outher without gripping.
Version 2 has been extended with nearly 2 mm to address this problem.

IKEA brackets for multi-curtain

It was drawn in Inventor, and I used a precision caliper to measure every detail.

author: Jooxoe3i

description.text:
UPDATE (8/8/17)

So, I noticed a file I missed..... It's the Y Axis Pulley Holder. If you're keeping up with me, I've also begun taking a list of vitamins for this printer. Unfortunately, I'm missing a few screws myself, which I'll be picking up tomorrow (8/9/10). This weekend, I'll be finalizing the full build list and making a video and taking pictures. Once I've done all of that, I'll be doing a lot of modifications to the model files, and creating Funbot i2!!!

UPDATE (7/12/2017)

I've begun updating the Wiki page at http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Funbot_i1 if anyone wants to view it. There's still quite a bit to do. Mainly gather a list of vitamins and start creating proper instructions. I'm likely going to create a "variations" page for this particular build. Any other ideas or suggestions can be PMed to me here. Thanks again!!!

UPDATE

I've received word from RepRapOsterlen! He said I can work on his Wiki page, so I'll start adding quite a bit over there. As he said, he hasn't been able to work on any of his designs lately due to scheduling conflicts, which I can absolutely understand.

Original

I've been looking at the Funbot i1 3D printer lately, and wanted to mix a few files and look at the instructions again. If anyone finds this, it's very, very WIP, but should be able to be made. I'll work on it a bit more as things go forward, and hopefully give a few instructions as well.

All other instructions are the same for the original Funbot. You can of course use either the 10mm rods or 3/8" rods, and this design is set to use either a M8 threaded rod, or lead screw/nut.

Edit: Checking to make sure all files are prepared, and noticed I had the amount of bushings backwards. It's proper now. Also added the 10mm version of the winged bushings.

comments.text: I've built 4 Funbots. One 3/8" rod, One 10mm rod, and two 8mm rods. All 4 are still running great for well over 2 years. In this time the only breakage has been a couple broken X/Pulley ends, The printed pulleys on the original (I use aluminum pulleys now), and 3 worn out extruders. I have bed leveling on one of the M8 versions, but you really don't need it. I switched from springs on the bed to High Temp Automotive silicone hoses and a 3 point mount. I haven't releveled a bed in 2 years, even after taking it back and forth to work several times. I recommend either Bronze bushings or LMU bearings over printed ones, keep the X axis as light as possible, and aluminum pulleys. I look forward in seeing the new updates.

comments.text: Will you be actively developing this? I already have a 3d printer, (a Wanhao i3 v2) and I was thinking about printing another printer, likely a Reprap, maybe to give a friend or to have a spare printer in case my main breaks down, or to use as a part farm.

comments.text: I've noticed that it hasn't been touched since around mid-2015, and I'm personally taking steps to create one myself. Currently, I'm only gathering resources. Once I've done that, and can provide clear instruction, I will likely go further into development, keeping with the original idea of a "lightweight easy to ship and assemble" and "extremely cheap to build and easy to get most parts nearby where you live" (quoted from the original description) printer. My current printer isn't up to par in true development, so it may take some time, but I do intend to truly look into this.
comments.author: wags_1

comments.text: Will this be designed for European or United States supplies?
comments.author: moebius_2033

comments.text: The original Funbot i1 was for both, and since I'm currently only gathering STLs, as of now, it is for both. All lengths, such as rod lengths and print area, are in Metric, but it's possible to use either 3/8" rods or 10mm rods. Screws and nuts are easily available in the US and Europe in Metric sizes, and the threaded rod can be either an M8 threaded rod or an M8 lead screw/nut set. I have personally been able to source all hardware parts from my local Lowe's hardware store. I used Amazon for all other parts, such as the Arduino/RAMPS, NEMA 17 motors, the MK8 extruder, and the couple bearings that will be needed. I haven't checked on the vitamins (screws, nuts, washers) yet, but I'm sure that I can source those from my local Lowe's as well.

author: discovercamp110

description.text:
A slight change to the (excellent) V29 whistle by @jzisa that was remixed to the (even more excellent) compact whistle by @jrclem

This version just takes the compact whistle and cuts out parts that aren't absolutely necessary for function. Instead of having the lanyard hole at the end, they take up the negative space created by the whistle chamber (however, they are quite small - intended for fine cord). Edges are rounded and areas made hollow to reduce weight and ensure the whistle will float. This sacrifices some durability, but I've found it to be more than durable enough for my uses.

The function of the whistle remains the same - incredibly loud. I've printed mine at 85% scale and it comes out to 2 grams printed with glow in the dark PLA at 20% infill. No supports necessary.

title: Garden Hose Push Fit Socket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
IMPROVED VERSION HERE https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2435474

A push-fit socket for those semi-standardized garden hose quick connect things for 3/4" garden hose threads. IT ACTUALLY WORKS AND HOLDS PRESSURE WITHOUT LEAKING though tolerances may depend on your printer, I printed it on a Taz 6. This is a WORK IN PROGRESS because the latch isn't quite sticky enough.

Requires vitamins: 4 x 6mm plastic airgun bullets (i.e. airsoft).

Requires cleanup after printing: Reaming out the holes in the center spindle to let the 6mm bb's protrude partly into the center.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Printed in ABS at medium resolution with no special settings.

It uses four 6mm plastic airgun BB's to lock the center piece in place. Ream out the holes in the center part until the BB's can just barely stick through the side, but not so much that they fall through. The locking sleeve can now be slid atop as an extremely tight fit, becoming loose again (though nearly unremovable) once the balls are fitting into the locking grooves.

The locking grooves hold the BB's fast when the sleeve is in the locked position, preventing the other half of the quick-connect from leaving. pushfit-002.jpg shows it in locked position, with the sleeve down.

Like most garden hose things, use proper hose washers to prevent leaks.

As usual, sources at my site: http://burningsmell.org/3d/pushfit/

title: Mavic Pro Getterback mount with optional flasher

description.text:
When flying out over deep water (obviously not a pool as picture) you can increase your chances for recovery with a Getterback locked to your Mavic Pro.

The Getterback (available from many sporting goods stores and Amazon) is designed to release a float after being submerged for any duration. It will release in 10 minutes and should allow for recovery in water up to 100'.

If you add the optional flasher, you can only increase your chances of finding the float in the water, especially if you're flying at night. The flasher will run on fresh batteries for a couple of days.

print_settings.Notes:: The collimator must be printed solid in order to be effective as a collimator. You will find it in its own .stl file.

description.text:
All students learn about radioactivity, and most have heard that the consequences include everything from Godzilla to spider senses. But few of them know we can safely measure the energy of radiation and do something called nuclear spectroscopy in an ordinary science lab.

Print yourself a simple beta radiation spectrometer from a Vernier Radiation Monitor, a couple of strong magnets, and a Vernier Rotary Motion Sensor. Note: A protractor can be used in place of the Rotary Motion Sensor for manual data collection.

In our setup, a radioactive source emits beta particles into a strong magnetic field. Magnets bend the path of the charged beta particles. The least energetic particles bend the most, emerging with a larger deflection angle, and the most energetic ones bend the least. So one can calculate the energy of a beta particle from the deflection angle. By slowly rotating a radiation source while measuring the radiation at the other side of the magnets, one can find the number of counts per minute at any given angle. A little physics converts the measured angle to a corresponding energy. The result is a spectrum of beta radiation that can be compared with published spectra.

Notes:

The collimator must be printed solid in order to be effective as a collimator. You will find it in its own .stl file.

title: 18650 Dual USB Mobile Power Bank Charger Case

description.text:
I bought this Dual USB charger module off ebay a while ago. Once it finally arrived from China, I started hunting around for a case but no luck. I didn't want to house it with batteries, rather, was looking for a stand alone case. In my application, I have a number of 18650 battery packs that I want to charge with an independent charger and to use it as a bench tool... so here's my take on it.

The charger that I designed this case around is found on ebay under the title "Dual USB 5V 1A 2.1A Mobile Power Bank 18650 Battery Charger PCB Module Board M".

Here's the e-bay link (as of today):
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Dual-USB-5V-1A-2-1A-Mobile-Power-Bank-18650-Battery-Charger-PCB-Module-Board-M/172341892151

The case is designed to have a 7.5mm outer diameter female barrel connector on the one side of the case (so I can plug in my charge cable). The lid is designed for M2 brass heatsets in the lid, and black oxide hex head screws to attach the lid to the base. Screws go in from the bottom. I'm sure you could alternatively use some self tappers. You'll figure it out.

If you find it useful, grab it, print it, and enjoy. Hope it serves you well. Lemme know what you think. Feedback is always appreciated.

Some of my other designs can be found here : http://www.corei64.com/store

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 mn

Infill:

title: Twisty vases via customizable polar graphs

description.text:
This is a customizable wavy vase or cup. In the Customizer, you specify polar graph formulas for the bottom and top, as well as a formula for varying the diameter, and a twist angle, as well as the wall thickness and the bottom thickness.

The design may not work if your graphs have sharp cusps.

The OpenSCAD file uses (and bundles) my tube mesh and function parser libraries.

Updates:

  • July 6-8, 2017: fix bug that cut off vases with too much flare; add slow-walls option

The code generates whole polyhedra at once using the tube mesh library.

The first iteration used minkowski() and subtraction to make the vase hollow. The result was super slow: 17 minutes for my test run. I then switched to approximating the curve normal in each slice, and using the curve normal to make an inset curve. Then I simply subtract that, and the result is much faster. I also added another method that intersects 8 copies of the solid vase to create the inner space, which in some cases will prevent overly thin walls; this is faster than the minkowski() method and slower than the inset curve method.

title: Eddy Current Brake for Vernier DTS Carts

description.text:
An eddy current brake is a non-contact braking system, most commonly used in trains and roller coasters. In an eddy current brake, magnets are used to induce eddy currents in a metal rotor or other metal part of the vehicle. According to Lenz’s Law, those induced currents create a magnetic field opposing the original field. The two opposing magnetic fields work to slow the vehicle, rather than applying a frictional force like a traditional braking system.

Chris Gaffney and Adam Catching’s article “Magnetic Viscous Drag for Friction Labs” in the Sept. 2016 edition of The Physics Teacher describes their investigation into eddy current braking. As an alternative to a traditional friction lab, their students slid magnets down a long aluminum ramp, slowed by the eddy currents they induced in the ramp.

As a company that sells a lot of aluminum tracks and magnets, it seemed natural to try it out ourselves. We designed and 3D-printed a simple magnet holder for our DTS carts. It holds up to 4 magnets about 2 mm off the surface of the dynamics track.

The attached graph shows the velocity of a DTS cart rolling on an inclined track, with either the eddy current brake (zero, two, or four magnets) or our Friction Pad installed. With zero magnets, the cart’s velocity increases linearly, as expected. With the Friction Pad installed on the cart, the velocity curve is similarly linear, albeit with a shallower slope.

The shape of the velocity curve differs when the eddy current brake is installed. As expected, the induced drag on the cart increases with the number of magnets installed. It is also apparent that the nature of the eddy current braking force is different than simple kinetic friction. For example, it appears that with four magnets installed, the cart reaches a terminal velocity in the four seconds shown.

title: Focussing aid for camera lenses (for precise focus)

description.text:
This is a collection of focusing aid for different diameters of lenses / focusser rings.

In astrophotography or macro photography it is essential to focus as precise as possible. By turning the focus ring on DSLR lenses by hand, it is quite difficult to lock down on the best focus possible (most likely you will be able to turn the focus ring by a degree precision). With this tool attached, it is possible to get really precise focus, as you will be turning a screw on one of the two parts. Which is increasing the precision 50-fold to 100-fold (depending on your skills).

The rings are designed for given diameters. The rings may flex for 2-3mm in diameter. I would recommend, lining the rings inner surface with velours tape. One ring has to be attached to the focus ring, the second ring has to be attached to the lens barrel (non-moving part)

What you will need:
1x ring with pin
1x ring with fork
2x conical knurled knob (from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2418824 )
2x flat knurled knob (from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2418824 )
2x M4x45mm or M4x50mm hex head for conical knurled knob
2x M4x40 hex head for flat knurled knob
4x M4 nut
M4 tap to cut threads
(hot) glue to attach screws in knobs

Current set of ring diameters is:
72mm (f), 74mm (f, p), 78mm (f, p), 80mm (p), 84mm (f, p)
f ... ring with fork
p ... ring with pin
If time permits, I may add further diameters on request!

description.text:
Montaraz is the first project I've started from zero for my home 3D printer. Design dates from 2015 so there are some flaws and things that I wouldn't do it like that again, and maybe need to be reworked... but if I keep retouching the model, I'm sure I will never release it.
Vehicle itself is made for 28mm miniatures from INFINITY (THE GAME), but you can use it in whatever setting you want, even in near future games.

All parts can be printed without supports except the hull, the back part is tricky and need supports.

Model is not "snap-fix" so you'll need glue to put it toghether. Unions are strong (hexagonal pyramids) so it is very sturdy. My advice is to build all exept one of the back legs and wheel, so you can finally glue the wheel to the leg and once dry adjust it to the model for the four wheels to make contact on the surface.

title: CPU Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is a box w/ a slider lid for a LGA1155 (37.5mm x 37.5mm) processor, but it can be scaled to fit most other processors. Google your processor at Intel ark to find its dimensions, then scale this model to fit in your favorite slicer (note: account for the walls when scaling).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10-15%

Notes:

The box in the images was printed on a 0.3mm Microswiss nozzle at 0.1mm layer height. You could probably get away with slightly larger layer height, but keep in mind this may impair the sliding action.

The original design did not have a slider lid. I wanted this case to stay closed during shipping without the use of adhesive, so I started the remix with traditional drawer-style rails, which worked but had steep overhangs that necessitated supports. The lid was also smooth, which made it difficult to grip much less figure out which direction to slide (when lid and case are the same color).

This final version features a textured lid for added finger grip and an obvious arrow to indicate the opening/sliding direction. I also changed the rails to a dove tail shaped rail to eliminate the need for printing supports.

This is a replica of the Federation Gunship Edens class, manufactured from 2500 to 2655, with an impressive total of 144 being built. FS Hood being destroyed by sabotage while in construction in 2599 and the FS Kimitai being abandoned on Altair III while almost complete. The first sub-class fielded only laser turrets, while the latter sub-class used a mix of laser and nuke cannons. Almost all surviving Edens class were upgraded by 2660 to carry all nuke cannons and many of the laser turrets were retired or used for planetary last ditch defense. This model is provided with both the beam turrets with shorter cone lasers or can also be fitted with the longer nuke slug cannon turrets which became more common. I would recommend printing 3 turrets of both types to represent a ship in early, mid and late sub-classes.
Known in service as the Ugly sisters, they were used extensively in system defense roles with dedicated interstellar engines and show a family resemblance to the latter exploration and cruiser classes also built by Titan-Millford Inc.

description.text:
Simple case for the Raspberry Pi 3 Model B

Update 2017/09/07: Adjusted the size of the cut outs by about 2mm and added different variations of the top part (full cut out logo, half cut out logo, no logo). I'm not sure about the "no logo" version, unless it might have not enough ventilation. But @PDBeal ask for it, so I've added it.

description.text:
This is a basket that fits inside where the used pods go. The basket will sit on the inner ledge and in the water at the bottom.

This allows for dry removal of the pods. Lift the basket and dump the pods and rinse the catch.
The best way is to dump before your next coffee (12-24 hours drying).

Less mess. Before I would have to drain against the sink and then dump the pods (if I didn't want water in the garbage).

The basket fits Verismo models 580 (not the newer ones).

Two version exist, one with the diamond screen and with solid walls.

Diamond prints (_net) with less material but takes more time.


Solid walls (_solid) more material but less time.

This set of parts was designed to use 1/2 inch EMT conduit to make a tripod grade rod holder. A grade rod is like a yardstick with precise markings and meant to be read from a distance. In my case, I have an old auto-level, a device that maintains a line-of-sight level with the earth. The auto-level, along with a grade rod, allows measurement of relative elevations between different points.
While using these tools, my assistant (wife) usually gets tired of holding the grade rod, or I may be on my own without assistance. I wanted a simple device to hold the grade rod up while I measure.
The main part, of course, is the tripod head, that holds 3 sections of conduit at 25 degrees from vertical. The inside of the head is hollowed out to save material. Also, I suppose on a windy day, I could hang some weight from the head with a string to make it more stable.
The double clamp allows 3 additional sections of conduit to be added for adjustability.
I made feet that fit the ends of the conduit just to keep them from getting packed with dirt. The spiked foot version may be useful to push down into the ground slightly for stability.
Updated version of the chuck holder.

title: MendelMax 1.5 with only one motor for Z-axis

description.text:
By using this solution one motor for the Z-axis can be replaced by two 32 teeth T2.5 pulleys and a 950mm T2.5 belt. This modification offers several benefits like:
  • less weight
  • less wiring
  • less noise
  • reduced costs
  • Z-axis can be moved by hand
  • No more parallelism adjustments of Z-axis

Bill of Materials (BoM):

  • These are the parts you'll need for the zig-zag solution:
    Print:

  • 2x SpannFix (holder for the tensioner pulleys)
  • 2x Pulley 625ZZ
  • 1x Lower Z Mount (with bearing instead of motor), from another thingiverse source.
    • Vitamins (to buy):
  • 4x M5 T-Slot nuts
  • 4x screw M5 x 10, socket head
  • 2x screw M5 x 30, hex head
  • Washers 5 mm, Qty. as required
  • 4x Bearing 625ZZ
  • 2x Pulley T2.5 / 32
  • 1x T2.5 closed belt, Length: 950mm
  • 2x Z-axis rod, Length: 340mm and 310mm (which are longer than the original ones), I use Tr 8x1,5
    • UPDATE:

  • As the zig-zag Solution isn't good for the durability of the belt another solution by just using an aluminium rail (see picture) seems to be quite effective.

    • So for the "triangular" solution you need this: Print:
  • Spanner Holder
    • Vitamins (to buy):
  • 20 x 20 aluminium profile, length: 25 cm
  • 3x M5 T-Slot nuts
  • 2x screw M5 x 20, socket head
  • 1x screw M5 x 10, socket head
  • 1x screw M5 x 80, hex head
  • Washers 5 mm, Qty. as required
  • Nut M5, Qty. as required
  • 2x Bearing 625ZZ
  • 2x Pulley T2.5 / 32
  • 1x T2.5 closed belt, Length: 950mm or 910mm
  • 2x Z-axis rod, Length: 340mm and 310mm (which are longer than the original ones), I use Tr 8x1,5
    • You havw to drill two 5mm holes into the aluminium profile to fix it on the frame. The first hole needs to be 2cm to the end, the second 12cm to the same end - which makes 10cm between theese holes. Countersink the holes on one side by using a 9mm drill (or larger) - as shown on the photo.

Here is a spool support that has a builtin bushing for the threaded rod. The spool support should now rotate freely without moving sideways on threaded rods and doesn't need nuts to stay in one place.

Print the spool support, twist the bushing using two prongs to liberate it, may need to use pliers. After this the bushing should rotate freely inside the main piece.

Feedback and suggestions welcome!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

60

Notes:

No rafts, no supports, easy print.
Except ...
The gap between the bushing and the main piece is 0.3mm, it should print fine on a moderately well calibrated printer. It doesn't to be super precise, as mine isn't. I usually print at 120% flow, but for this i had to go 100% otherwise the bushing just wouldn't separate.

I printed at 60% infill, 100% should also work (zero might too ;)

So now i've merged version 1 (which had ball bearings)https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067830 and version 2 (with uses springs to hold the spool)https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2169547, trying to merge better features of each.

This my modified version of the TheDrunkenGod's power supply covers remix for the Tevo Tarantula.

title: Crank Boot for mountain bike cranks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple crank protector (Crank Boot) for mountain bikes. It comes in handy if you don’t want to dent or scratch your cranks when riding in rough terrain.

The crank boots are designed with little wiggle room on the sides if for some reason your cranks are larger than averaged. These are tested on two different bikes with a SLX crank set, the crank boots held up in both cases and survived many rides through woods and my local downhill park.

NOTE This should not be a permanent solutions since they will wear out much quicker than injection molded crank boots, but these are a great temporary solution and have proven to withstand lots of abuse. These are just nice to print if your crank boots break and your to impatient to wait a few days for the new ones to arrive :)

Hope you guys enjoy these crank boots, let me know how I can improve them!

print_settings.Notes:: Printed using PLA with PVA for Support.

description.text: Print, Clean out screw holes (if support material is used), Tap threads into screw holes (using for example SPAX Multi-Purpose Construction Screws #8 x 2 inches), Cut heads off screws (leaving about 1 - 1.25 inches) and use locking pliers to screw the cut-off end of the screw into each hole. Leave about 0.43 inches of the screw protruding to clean 2.5 inch or larger mortars. Longer screws can optionally be used and more can be left protruding to clean larger mortars. 20 screws are required. Completed tool can be threaded onto a broomstick or paint handle for cleaning mortars. Submitter is not responsible if tool is used for other than the intended purpose.

title: 3D Model of the Pavlok Module and Wristband, For Accessory Design Reference
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Are you a Pavlok user interested in experimenting with your own accessory designs? If you want to 3D print or laser cut your own Pavlok wristband/necklace/belt-clip/fanny-pack/anything, these models can help! They represent the dimensions of the Pavlok module as it is manufactured. A model of the original "Pavlok 1" silicone wristband (originally prototyped in TPU on a Flashforge!) is also included. We've uploaded them here in multiple formats, so importing them into your CAD software should be a piece of cake!

Don't have CAD software to experiment with? We recommend www.onshape.com as an excellent (and free!) CAD package.

author: parcem16

description.text:
This is my 360 degree wind turbine (which is still a work-in-progress) taken from the original design by me2space, you can find his design here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1767153.

Credit goes to me2space for the turbine blades, hub and base, everthing else i have re-designed.

the original design stands at a height of about 14 inches,however, this one stands at a height of around 26inches (2ft+), and has a fully functional 360 degree blade/motor turret.

i liked the original desgin so much i decided to go one little step further, i increased the general size of the WT to 170%, but to still try and keep it simple, and easy as possible to print.

most of the larger parts of the model was printed in 0.3 for speed, the smaller parts were printed in 0.15 for quality and fitting. ( i do intend to print all parts in 0.15 for the final build )

360 DEGREE TURRETT

as for the 360 degree turrett, i tried to keep it as simple as possible, and use what i had laying around the house for the electrical connction, so i managed to find an old router and power cable, so i de-soldered the DC power socket form the board of the router, and voila, i have a simple 360 degree capable connection :) if anyone has a new way of doing this Please let me know, ...... See a Need, Fill a Need......(Robots 2005)

i have inclued a few pics to show kind of how its put together. as for the top of the tower, the Cable Pin is pushed inside the Pivot bottom first, then those two are pushed into the top of the tower, be careful its is a really tight fit ( i had to bash it in with something lol ) make sure when u fix the 360 turrett bottom, to the top of the tower, you have the tower seperated.

TURBINE TOWER

the tower comes in 3 sections. i tried to print the tower in two sections but my printer only goes 180mm high, so i had to print it horizontally & diagonally across the bed, but ended up being a horrible print, so thats why i split in into 3 and printed it vertically.

the DC cable slides through the Cable pin and down through the tower. you may want to add a little glue/hot melt glue into the Pin and Cable to stop the wire twisting with the rotation of the motor mount.

MOTOR MOUNT

the motor mount was increased in size, either to hold a bigger motor, or small motor with a gearing system to increase RPM of the small DC motor. i am working on a desin for some kind of modular bay/cage to hold sed items.

I will continue to update the model and post. if anyone does like this model and has any ideas on how to improve it, Please feel free to comment :)

Thanks for now,

G.

title: MobyStick - Whale USB and SD holder

description.text:
I wanted to make a more interesting and original USB and SD-card holder than the standard square ones I found on Tingyverse.
So here it is. I remixed it from Smiley The Whale, but I had to remodel most of it as the original scan was not very clean and there were pockets and non-manifolds.
Used MeshLab to lower poly-count, SketchUp to do the actual remodelling and FreeCad to clean up the errors generated by SketchUp. I've included a version with supported Tail (Supports added in Meshmixer so you will have to rotate it 90ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ°. I printed this version.) and also a version of the remodelled Whale without the USB holes for anyone wanting to make their own stuff. 06.02.14 Updated the files, now the SD and USB slots have 0,4mm tolerance to allow proper fit.
Printed on the K8200 3D-Printer, with 20% infill, 0.2 layer hight, using white PLA

title: Multiplying and Squaring Binomials Using the BOX Method

description.text:
This is a lesson on showing students a method for multiplying binomials. This method is intended to prevent students from making mistakes when multiplying two binomials, as well as to see and understand the geometric properties of multiplying two binomials. To extend this lesson to next next lesson in the learning segment I would include squaring a binomial using the same method. The student would be able to see how the two middle terms cancel out.

The common core standards CCSS for this are...

Perform arithmetic operations on polynomials.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSA.APR.A.1
Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.

I designed this thing using Tinkercad software. I simply used the "BOX" option and changed the dimensions when suitable as well as using square holes where suitable. I used this to create all of the 3D objects. I used the text application to include the labels of the mathematics on the pieces. I grouped the different objects in order to create the final objects.
CCSS

About the Lesson Plan The lesson is designed to give the students a tangible way of understanding why the BOX METHOD of multiplying two binomials works. By teaching the students with tangible pieces from the 3D printer they will more easily be able to comprehend what is going on. This just lead students to gain a better understanding of multiple expressions for when we multiply polynomials, and also use other methods such as FOIL and Double Distribute. The students should acquire a higher level of fluency with regard to multiplying expressions from this activity. Box method example of (x+2)(x+3).

Lesson Plan SET UP
  • The students will receive a worksheet with a list of problems which are binomial that they are to multiply using the box method which I will have already modeled on the SmartBoard.
  • I will break the students into groups of 3-4 to work on this assignment.
  • I will give each group one square piece with a hollowed out middle, and multiple rectangles with binomials inscribed upon them (which correspond to the problems on their worksheets). I will also give each group multiple squares with the monomials inscribed on them (which will allow them to solve the problems and obtain their answers).
    • PROCEDURE

  • The students will read the problems on the worksheet that I give them. For example say problem 1. is (x+3)(x+5). They will then look for the two rectangles with the binomials (x+3) and (x+5) inscribed up them. The will align each term of the binomial with each vacant spot on their square grid, they will correspondingly do this on their worksheet. They will then multiply each of the corresponding terms, the solutions to each of the terms multiplied will be one of the square pieces which I gave them. For example the top left would be x*x so the student would have a square piece with an x^2 on which they would fill this spot with. They would also record this on their paper. So, each time the students would be multiplying 4-times and would be filling in their grid 4-times. They would then combine the two like terms to give a final answer. They would also be doing the same on their worksheet.

  • I would have the same worksheet in Smart Notebook file on the Smart Board in the classroom. As I monitored the students progress and checked in with their groups I would have the group with the correct answers put them up on the Smart Board. (The students enjoy writing on the SmartBoard at this age/grade).

  • We would continue like this until we finished all the problems. I would address any misconceptions which I noticed arose during the lesson. I would go over some of the problem before class ended. I would then end by assigning homework or notifying students if their would be an assessment or whatever announcements that I had to make before class ended.
    • An example of a problem with the box method multiplying (x+5)(x+3), This video can help you remember the Box Method if your forgot it. Steps and examples are provided!
We need -3D printing, worksheets, SmartBoard/Smart Notebook.

• Multiplying Binomials
  • multiplying variables
  • multiplying constants
  • Box Method
40-45 minutes

What needs to be done prior in order to enact the lesson. Worksheets.
Smart Board/ Smart Notebook Presentation.
3D Printing Materials (See pictures).

Step 1

Students will receive the materials.

  • A box with 4 squares holes in it.
    -[A bag of] Rectangular pieces with binomials inscribed on them.
    -[A bag of] Square pieces which fit perfectly into the box with monomials inscribed on them.

Students will multiply these binomials using the box method.

Students will be reminded that multiplication of real numbers is commutative, so it will not matter what order they do these problems in, they will still obtain the same answer if they have done everything correctly.

The students will have their box with the 4 square holes in front of them. They will look at the problem for examples (x+3)(x+5). They will find the two rectangular pieces from their bag that say (x+3) and (x+5) and arrange these pieces on the top and side of their box so that each term lines up with one of the holes.

The students will then multiply out each term and select the appropriate product from their bag of squares with monomials and constants written on them. The students will fill in their box with the 4 products while also calculating them on their worksheet.

The students will remove the pieces from their box and line them up from left to right, they will then write this on their worksheet for that problem. Lastly the students will combine "like terms" and write their final answer on their worksheet. I will have students with the correct answer put them on the Smart Board. They will repeat this 10 times for the following problems.

1.) (x+3)(x+5)=
2.) (x-1)(x+3)=
3.) (x-1)(x+5) =
4.) (x-1)(x-7)=
5.) (-x+2)(-x-4)=
6.) (x-1)(-x+2)=
7.) (-x-4)(x-1)=
8.) (-x-4)(x-7)=
9.) (x+3)(-x-4)=
10.) (x+5)(-x+2)=
After I have printed this I will update those sections.

title: CR-10 Mosaic Palette Scroll Wheel Holder

description.text:
I created a holder for the Mosaic Palette Scroll Wheel. The CR-10 is a "movable" bowden-type extruder system making it difficult to get proper placement and alignment of the scroll wheel. Mounting the scroll wheel to move up the Z axis with the bowden assembly was the perfect solution.

When I began this project, there were NO available mounts like this. All I had was a picture where another user came up with the idea. Myself and others were not able to find the .stl online (I searched and searched) so a few of us on the CR-10 FaceBook user group decided to design our own to give other users a choice. Positive feedback and helpful negative feedback is welcomed.

I'm new to design, and this was my first real design on Fusion360 outside of a fidget spinner ;)

description.text: Here is a little introductory geometry lesson on volumes of solids, oblique vs. right. The students will measure the printed solids to determine if there are two solids that prove Cavalieri's Principle true. Students will also be directed to find alternative ways to solve for the volume of a oblique solid

The shapes for this lesson were designed on Tinkercad.com. I basically used cylinders and just changed the dimensions. To create the oblique solids, I copied and pasted disks and placed them one on the other, then offset them the same distance in the same direction.
CCSS
This activity is meant to be used as either an introductory activity, or as a lab activity.
Printed Solids, Printed Worksheet, ruler or measuring tape

• abstract thinking
  • applying properties
  • hands on mathematics
  • volume
  • Cavelieri's Principle
15-20 minutes

comments.text: To demonstrate this principle, don't you need to have same area / different shape pieces? E.g. squares, triangles.
comments.author: zapta

print_settings.Notes:: This was printed in PLA

description.text:
The challenge I tried to meet with this design is to make a design that could chain together but that would not come apart if you randomly shook and flexed it.
The two different pieces will only go together (or come apart) in one particular orientation. In this way it is almost a puzzle. Not sure if I need to post now to do it.
The full size print is (I think) big enough that a child can't choke on it. I am not really sure what the official dimensions should be, does anyone know?
The smaller print I printed at 50% scale which makes it 1/8 the size. Seems to be about right for a small child. With PLA at 50% scale it seems to be easily broken right down the middle. I will have to try it a bit larger.

It is not really configurable since the dimensions are fairly dependent on each other. I have included the source file so that you can try playing with it if you want.

The bars across the back are actually there for strength, but I think they look ok. I thought of making them a customizable letter, but I needed more strength than that.

My original design was going to include a small piece that joined the top and bottom on the other side, but not affect the ability to take it apart. It turned out that was not the weak point. The weak point was straight down the middle between the two loops, thus the 4 bars.

Any suggestions or comments?

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

This design needs supports. It helps with keep the round pins round and smooth, although these are usually fairly small supports. It is also needed to support the upper loop.
I print the pins lying down with the funny hole pointing up.
I print the links on their edge with the semi circular piece down. Supports needed to hold up the second loop.
For the infill I found that setting the
Support Infill Angles
to 45 worked well. I also used a Support Pillar Resolution of 1.5mm

I did not create this STL. Credit to Keith Ottlinger. These whistles are being donated to the family of Carson Hall, for fundraising efforts. Here is original post from the 3D Printing Club facebook page:

CALL TO ACTION!
I'll commit to printing a spool for the cause.
Dear 3D Printing Club,
I am writing to tell you about a very special little boy and an opportunity that we may have to help support his family. Carson Hall is 5 years old and he lives with his mother, father, and little brother in Hutchinson, KS. One year ago, Carson was diagnosed with a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) brain tumor, a fatal pediatric form of cancer. A child diagnosed with DIPG today faces the same prognosis as a child diagnosed 40 years ago. There is still no effective treatment and no chance of survival. Only 10% of children with DIPG survive for 2 years following their diagnosis, and less than 1% survive for 5 years. The median survival time is 9 months from diagnosis, but Carson has already survived a whole year and his family is making the most of their time with him.
I came to know Carson and his family 5 years ago when his mom and dad owned and operated food booths next to our face painting booth at the Kansas State Fair. They are a very hard working family. I remember his mom being pregnant with him and then later pregnant with their second son. Last year we found out the terrible news of Carson’s diagnosis. All the vendors at the fair became aware and gave Carson the opportunity to make as many memories as possible. Understandably so, Carson’s family has a goal to make the most of his time on Earth, no matter what the cost. They have never asked for a dime but when I followed Carson’s story on Facebook via the page “Carson’s Crusaders”, I knew that I wanted to do whatever I could to help.
My husband got a 3D printer in March and he started making toys, including whistles. This is where I got the idea for the project. My hope is that I may receive some help from an experienced 3D printer programmer to write a program for a whistle that would have Carson’s initials (CH) on it, along with a loop so that a lanyard may be attached. Once a pattern has been made, I was hoping that the members of the 3D Printing Club would be willing to make whistles and donate them to the cause by September 2nd, 2017.
The plan would be to sell them at the Kansas State Fair and charge $5 a piece with all proceeds going to the family. When I asked Carson’s mom if I could create this fundraiser she said, “I am touched and you have my blessing if you decide to organize that.” I also called the head of the Kansas State Fair and she was excited about the idea.
If you have the time and resources to help execute this project, I would be forever grateful. Carson and his family need all the sH2upport they can get.
Sonja Ottlinger

description.text:
This is a tilted LCD display case and accompanying name panel for the Rigidbot 2 (RB2).

Now those that have RB2's without LCD's can have a way to install a stock one and those that already have one can now view it easier. These parts will replace either original panel configuration.

There is a minimal amount of post processing required on the upper tabs of the tilted LCD case to allow printing without support material. See post processing below.

Pop the name plate in top edge first and then the LCD case the same way. You may have to push up on the name plate tabs to get them started and then they pop in place. Pushing up on the bottom face of the tilted LCD case will pop it in place. By reaching inside and pushing up on the bottom tabs you can remove both panels.

As with all my printer parts these are precision parts. For best results it is highly recommended that you use calibrated filament using the method found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301

Notes:

The top tabs of the tilted LCD case have self supporting features on the underside of the outer edges so support material does not need to be turned on. These small wedges will need to be removed before inserting into the frame of the printer.

LCD case tab clean up

The upper tabs on the LCD case have small built in support tabs on the outer edges to allow for printing without support material. These tabs need to be trimmed off before you insert the case into the printer frame.

Removal from the bed can be accomplished using a sharp 3/4" chisel, bevel side down, and prying up as you rotate it across the bevel. Work your way around the edges and corners till the part pops off the bed.

This is a replicate of the famous exploration cruiser gunboats known as the Dido class. Some 505 were built from 2455 and many are still in service now. The most common configuration was to field it with a small exploration craft and a single triple laser beam turret. The designers found that they could use a triple laser rather than the normal double shorter ranged laser used on most ships by using the excess of power normally used to operate the four extra large sensor arrays and the long range radar.
In times of intense conflict some ships used two triple turrets instead of the scout ship, and for some missions, two scout ships were carried instead of the turret. The ship carries a single missile launchers which is also used to launch probes for its primary mission.
A major problem in combat for this class is the lack of dedicated shields. It carries bridge generated shielding which is designed to deflect stray asteroids but the ship is not designed to go toe to toe against alien or rival cruisers of a similar size, despite its impressive firepower.
The small scout ship has no offensive capacity, although on at least one occasion they have been fitted out with a missile launcher in the cargo area.
Designed and produced by Titan-Milford Inc.

title: Better Tensioner / Pulley / Idler Wheel for Geeetech (pics to prove it)!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[SEE BELOW FOR UPDATES]

After chasing down the reason for Y/X layer issues on a Geeetech Pro B/C 3D printer, I realized Z wobble was only half the battle! The wrong/inappropriate idler wheel is another issue! Possibly more of contributing factor to x/y layer inconsistencies than Z wobble. Just picture that smooth wheel as the toothed belt comes across it... a tooth touches it... a tiny force is applied... next is a gap... it goes back down... then another tooth... back up... back down... back up... and so on... and so on... I'm not taking credit for the realization, I know see that many have figured this out before me! Including @TNS whose Anet solution to this problem is what I based mine on for the Geeetech printer. Since I never found a totally ideal solution; a toothed wheel that a) printed well, b) was just the right match for the stepper gear pulley (20 tooth, ~12mm wide at the teeth) and c) I wanted it to use bearings so it didn't fail after a few prints.

So between the excellent gear customizer on here and some simple modeling in TinkerCAD, I came up with what I believe is a good solution. I have pics to show that it did indeed improve my print quality, and by quite a margin I must say! I hope the pics do it justice! It's not a perfect, and I tried to highlight the layer imperfection especially in the pics, so when it isn't lit that way intentionally the prints look amazing! So much more uniform, even and smooth, with far less surface 'noise'. An occasional slightly over/under extruded line still, but what an improvement! It also didn't effect my calibration at all, as you can see in the pics the printer still produces a fairly accurate 20mm cube!

I don't know if it's 100% because of the teeth, or if the spacers help too (less play in the whole thing... but I'm amazed at how much better my prints look with this! I hope it helps some other people too! I've only tested on my own Geeetech Pro C, but it should work on some other printers (definitely the Pro B, maybe i3X...). Leave a comment if you use it on something else and I'll list it here as compatible!

UPDATE: after a few days of printing I had one pulley wheel fail. The side support was warped from my cooler not really getting air to the back when I had printed it, so the flaw allowed the belt ride up. Really, I was too conservative with those side supports anyways, so I used customizer and made a new one (v2) with much beefier sides! I'm still using an original (v1) pulley wheel on Y just to see how it holds up. I have a feeling it's not a design flaw, but just a print flaw. The new one should print well even with inadequate cooling (i.e. a stock Geeetech setup)! It also fits in the holder a better too, since it's a little wider (2mm wider than v1), but it's still a bit (~0.5mm) thinner than the metal pulley wheel, so fit won't be an issue. I had originally wanted to keep it smaller so would be compatible with more holders and to allow space for it to center itself, but I think we need the added strength. If I hadn't been there to stop the print it might have ruined my GT-2 belt, and I don't want anyone's GT-2 belt on my conscience...

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2138421

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=2138421

Printer:

Geeetech Pro C

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed with a 0.4 nozzle. however 0.3 would have been more appropriate for this, I believe. Get a good start layer! These are small so if the start is not perfect they will not be good. A small round file (or a rolled tube of fine sandpaper) is helpful to get the m3 screws to fit (see photos). I put the knurls around the spacer so you can grip it when filing, but don't go too far; the screws should be a snug fit and not too easy to push through! It's a more solid part in the end than the m4 variant.

I made certain that these parts are able to be printed with no supports at all. I printed mine at 0.1mm layer height, but it's really not necessary. Even 0.2 should be fine, I would imagine, but why not just use 0.1 since it's such a quick print anyways.

Just don't forget that 100% infill, and maybe use a little extra heat to ensure everything bonds together fully (I printed mine at 210C with PLA). Since I used a larger nozzle I also reduced the flow by 10%. I don't know if the extra voodoo is necessary but It's an integral part of your printer, so a little extra attention here will pay off!

In the pics i did something like an 'exploded' view the best I could in TinkerCAD, I think that explains what to do better than I can, but here goes anyways: I suggest doing the extra work and printing the little spacers for the m3 screws! You'll need two MR84ZZ (4x8x3) bearing just right. Also Traxxas 7019 bearings are an exact match and very high quality, and usually in stock at HobbyTown (or other hobby shops that RC cars). The MR84ZZ's are also the same bearings Geeetech provides with the stock pulley wheels, but the quality was bad with mine. There's also a little 'shelf' on both the m3 and m4 spacer that I added to make sure it only contacts the inner part of the bearing, allowing the rest of it to spin freely. I haven't tested the m4 version, but I believe it should work (but let me know, please)! The 20 tooth wheel I designed in customizer is set up to hold the two bearings, and the spacers should fit and have some clearance so they don't contact it at all. This way even if your pulley holder is snug, it will push on the spacer and still avoid contact with the parts that need to spin freely (an improvement over the stock pulley as well).

Really, it's a quick print even at slow speeds, but the parts are tiny and really close to the limit of 3D printing accuracy, so I'd recommend printing 4-5 wheels and maybe a 8-10 spacers... that way you can pick the absolute best of the best for your printer (and have a few spares on hand) I don't think my v1 wheel ever would have failed if I had done that to begin with! But that said, PLEASE USE VERSION 2! I believe it's much less likely to fail.

author: AlcatrazSkywalker

description.text:
A friend was hosting a large party and wanted to serve mini tacos. She couldn't find any commercial holders that she liked so she asked me to help. I found a "standard size" one that she liked so I redesigned it in Fusion 360 to be smaller. Because the critical measurements are parameters in F360 you can make it any size you want!

I printed in clear eSun PETG and it came out frosty and looks very nice. Choose holiday colors for other special occasions.

Fusion360 design modeled after the original.

There are two basic parts, the "2-slot" and the "end". If you are in F3D you need to use "Copy As New" for as many of the "2-slot" as you need then the same for one End. Join them all together and use Combine to make it one component. The last is important because my slicer (Simplify3D) printed each part touching but separate; this is not optimal. Once I used Combine it printed as one whole which makes it much stronger.

description.text:
This puppet was made with my husband Keith Ozar http://www.thingiverse.com/OZAR at the Metropolitan Museum of Art MakerBot Hackathon. We felt so bad for the "Standing Female Deity, possibly Durga" without her arms- now she is definitely Durga!
Keith captured the head with 123D catch and
I modeled the body and arms in Blender from turnaround photos I took in the gallery. We printed the body on our Thing-O-Matic at home after the first day and printed the head and arms on a Replicator at the event on day 2. It was a whirlwind and I wish the parts fit together a little better, but as my second MakerBot project ever- I think we did a good job. We wanted to share what we accomplished at this awesome event and will continue to refine this! This design is inspired by the old fashioned "Jumping Jack" toy.

The arms are drilled with two holes each. I used a 1/16" drill bit for the hole with the string and a 3/32" hole for the machine screw. Make sure you have some play in that hole so the arms moves freely. Print the back piece and the arms with 25% infill so they stand up to drilling. I used some cap headed machine screws-1/4" in length. An improvement would to add some pilot holes into the design to cut out some wonkiness.
Each set of arms are ganged together with a piece of 12lb line so you can operate each pair separately. You could tie each pair to the lower pair so you only have one string coming out the bottom.  Tie the string on the arms before you screw them to the back. I used some glue on my knots so they don't come undone. Pre-drill a hole for your machine screws and make it pretty small so you can self tap into the plastic. Don't overtighten the screw- leave a little play. Once you put the arms onto the back- then tie your arm pairs together.
Super glue the printed parts together from the bottom up. I'm loving the krazy glue with the brush. Remember to thread your lines through the lower half as you work and add a keyring at the end. The sarong and hat were made of thin spandex and attached with toupee tape (clear double sided tape)- no sewing.
Think about what objects she could be holding...
Puppet Show!!!

comments.text: Brilliant!!

description.text:
Hello All! This is Version 4 of the Neustruder as seen on https://forum.voltivo.com/showthread.php?tid=8450.

This has a slight cutout where it mounts to the stepper motor to account for the thickness of the plate that the motor mounts to. Uploaded are both versions to use the fitting that came with the CR10 or to use the larger 10mm fitting that's on the stock version.

This does need a mk8 (E3D hobgoblin recommended) gear to function. it will not work with the stock spur gear.

*About this block
This is a block that aims to completely lock down the filament from the second it touches the drive gear until it gets extruded out of the hot end. This allows it to successfully extrude at high speeds standard and flexible filaments alike. There are no springs to adjust tension, as the pressure from the 608ZZ Bearing will be controlled by four (4) M3x.5x50mm Screws. Works well at high and low speeds and has VERY good filament grip.

*Materials Required*****
--Printed
1x Upper Block
1x Lower Block
1x Axle
--Purchased
1x Mk8 5mm ID 8mm OD Hobbed Gear
1x 608ZZ bearing
4x M3x.5x30mm
4x M3x.5x50mm Screws
4x M3 Nuts
1-2 Pneumatic 10mm OD bowden adapters. The block is designed to be tapped and these will screw in.

**Printing instructions***
Print at your normal "quality" speeds without supports for V3.5 and with supports for V4.
It works well at 25% infill 3 shells 3 upper and bottom layers.

*Assembly instructions
1) Mount the 608ZZ bearing on the axle.
2) Place the axle in the slot in the upper block.
3) Slide the Mk8 Gear on to the shaft of the Nema 17 Stepper. Slightly tighten set screw.
4) Fasten the lower block to the Nema 17 motor using the M3x.5x30 screws using the front-facing holes.
5) Position the Mk8 Gear so that the teeth align with the Filament Channel. Tighten the set screw(s)
6) Place the upper block assembly in the lower block with the slot facing down onto the lower block so that the bearing fits in the groove.
7) Slide the M3 50mm Screws starting from the upper block through the entire assembly. Fasten with the M3 nuts on the other end. DO NOT TIGHTEN. IF YOU TIGHTEN BEFORE YOU HAVE FILAMENT IN THE DRIVE, YOU WILL HAVE A BAD TIME.

You now have a fully assembled block. To begin extruding, thread the filament through the block so that you see filament on the other side. With the gear turning, tighten the long screws rotating around the top of the block until filament starts to move. Tighten all screws to this tension, and then give the screws 1-2 more complete revolutions to ensure that it will extrude properly. Flexible filaments may require additional revolutions to properly extrude. At this point, happy printing!
