description.text:
STLs and full BOM are now available!

FuseBox2

Github: https://github.com/alexyu132/fusebox2
Update 3/1/18: Add double length alignment jig for 2040 access holes.
Update 1/24/18: Strengthened x-end tabs to reduce gantry twisting.
Update 11/14/17: Modified extruder arm to allow for greater tension and prevent bottoming out on smaller diameter extruder gears.

An affordable and robust CoreXY printer loosely based on the original FuseBox. Materials cost ranges from $300-400 largely depending on what hotend and electronics you choose to use.

Videos

Marlin 2 Speed Test: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aUQ9sjp_YzY
Benchy print: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cd1lirX5iP4
Movement test: https://youtu.be/IUSiRgaVAkE

Specifications and Features

  • Rigid 2020(top and sides)/2040(bottom) aluminum extrusion frame
  • Non-crossing CoreXY belt path
  • 210x200x210mm build area
  • 390x340x412mm size
  • MK2 or MK3 PCB heatbed with 3 point leveling
  • Strong part cooling blower (4020s)
  • E3D V6 or Lite6 + 40mm cooling fan and Bowden extruder
  • 24v + 32 bit electronics recommended

Improvements over original FuseBox

  • Slightly more compact
  • Slightly larger build area
  • 2020 frame for much greater rigidity
  • Belt tensioning improvements - much easier to tension and screw-clamped to prevent slipping out
  • Screw-clamped bearing and rod mounts - no more structural zip ties
  • Proper belt idlers - eliminates belt rubbing
  • (Optional) Extrusions joined via tapped ends + screws instead of corner brackets
  • Lowered part count - y rods integrated into motor and idler mounts
  • Vertical gantry for easier hotend installation/removal and better cooling
  • Better endstop mounting and easier adjustability
  • Robust electronics mounting with integrated display and IEC switch/fuseholder mounts - PSU flipped upside down so cooling fan doesn't interfere with heatbed

Printer:

Any well-calibrated printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

20-50%

Notes:

Some parts require your printer to be decent at bridging (carriage, idler blocks).

PETG or other temperature resistant filament should be used for the hotend cooling duct and is also recommended for the bed mounts. PLA is fine for the rest of the printed parts. 1.2mm walls/top/bottom and 40-50% infill work well for the structural pieces. For non-structural pieces like the display enclosure, you can drop the infill % and shell thicknesses.

Finishing printed parts

The hotend carriage has a piece of integrated support under the fan duct. Simply peel it off the finished part.

Make sure to get rid of stringing or other rough areas where the linear bearings and rods attach to make installing those parts easier. Some parts may have a tight fit depending on your printer.

Connecting extrusions

FuseBox2 does away with corner brackets and instead uses a tap and drill method to join the extrusions - this results in a lower part count, a cleaner appearance, and likely greater rigidity.

To connect 2 extrusions perpendicularly, use an M5 tap to tap the end of the first extrusion. On the second extrusion, drill an access hole where you want the first extrusion to connect. Partially screw in a 12mm M5 bolt to the end of the first extrusion, and slip its head into the channel of the second extrusion. Tighten down to attach the pieces rigidly together.

A more detailed explanation of how to connect extrusions using this method is available here: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?177,601562

1. Materials: 3d printed parts, 4 screws, 3 washers, 1 traction spring, 1 bearing.
  2. Assemble the spring to the rachet.
  3. Assemble the rachet to the “Bar support” part. Put a washer in between.

title: Stryfe Wire Channel (with and without Volt Meter Mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an upgraded wire channel for the Nerf Stryfe. It adds 5mm of space for wire so you can fit 16awg wire and volt meter wire. There are 2 versions of this design, with Volt Meter mount and without, so you can use 16awg wire without having the volt meter mount in the way if you're rather go that route. It was designed to take M2 *6mm screws and this voltage meter: http://foamblastshop.com/product/volt-meter/ Wire from voltage meter is long enough to reach the jam door switch. Make sure you use the 3 pin switch from the stock loom and test which pins work for the application. The 2 pin switches will not work.

This was designed for my printer and some of the holes might be too tight or loose depending on your printer's accuracy. I have included the STEP file for both models so you can change them for personal use.

description.text:
Remixed Kizinfo's original Logitech Quickcam Pro 9000 Telescope case from here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:763822

Took away the telescope part and the back fan cooling (wasn't needed for this). Also added a sleeve to mount to a gooseneck clamp so that I could get a perfect angle for remote viewing via Octoprint.

Used Tinkercad to edit the original STL's and block out what I didn't need and add what I did. Still quite a newbie but I do find Tinkercad to be really easy!

You'll need supports for the sleeve/gooseneck mount. I tried it without and it failed. Sliced it in Simplify3D and man those supports are just the bees knees.

There is 1 .stl for the lid and 3 different .stl(s) for the bottom case.

1) NoMount: just the case section without a gooseneck mount. (create your own!)
2) TopHang: for hanging the webcam from a suspended platform. Printed a test in AMZ3D White PLA at 200C attached (3mm).
3) BottomMount: the one I used and printed in AMZ3D Black PLA (2mm resolution). For mounting from the bottom.

Added an M5 screw hole for the gooseneck sleeve, ended up not using it as it was a perfect fit and gravity keeps the webcam case in place.

These 3-way 1x2 joiners can be used to create many types of frames, tables, stands, etc I created them so I could build a simple enclosure (similar to the Ikea Lack Table) for my 3d printers.

There are 2 parts. A left and right joiner which are mirrors of each other. Simply cut 1x2's to length and slide them into the joiners. Make sure you account for the depth of the joiner when making your measurements.

In the photos you can see the first table I made with this. I will add sides (x3) and a top. Then mount a spool holder on the top. The inside will be lined with egg crate material for sound dampening. The front will have a clear acrylic piece with hinges.

The Fusion 360 file is available if you'd like to have it.

title: Reach 3D Hot End Carriage, Fan Mount, and Z Probe Carriage

description.text:
Hot End Carriage: Removable carriage that doesn't affect the Z Probe. This design allows for quick swaps of hot ends, laser module, pen, etc. Carriages for the other items have not been designed as of yet.
Materials:
1 x 30x30mm fan
2 x M5x60 bolt
2 x M5 Nuts
2 x M3x25 Bolt
4 x M3x20 Bolt
6 x M3 Nut

Fan Mount: Uses a 50mm radial fan. The fan is held in with a M3x25 bolt.You may need to redrill and tap the hole. I printed it with the wrong hole size so I didn't have the ability to tap the hole and just used a longer M3 bolt and a nut. The reason for the hole is to allow the radial fan to pivot out of the way in order to access the M5 nut to remove the entire carriage.
Materials:
1 x 50mm radial fan
1 x M3x25 bolt
1 x M3 washer
1 x M3 Lock Washer

Z Probe Carriage: Z Probe Carriage allows micro adjustments with the M3 screw from the top and also houses the X end stop.The 4 washers are to make sure the bolt ends are flush to not interfere with the z probe.
Materials:
1 x M3x50 Bolt
1 x M3 Lock Nut
1 x #4 Screw
2 x M5x30 Bolt
4 x M5 washers
2 x M5 Nuts

description.text: I really enjoyed Robert's original scan, but I wanted to try carving this piece using my CNC machine, and that meant repairing a lot of the models holes and artifacts. Since I've been teaching myself Sculptris I figured that would be a good place to start. Unfortunately unlike its more robust cousin Z-Brush, Sculptris doesn't have a very robust mirror tool, so I was forced to mirror the entire left side to fix the missing pieces on the right side. Afterwards I did quite a bit of clean-up, smoothing and making things more defined. I really like the way this turned out, and it's not to bad for a first try at Sculptris.

print_settings.Notes:: I use Simplify3D extensively on a variety of printers and shortly I'll be providing detailed instructions on how to print Simula for the best results.

description.text:
Simula is an Arduino based Artificial Life project and these files and the related software are open source using Creative Commons - Share Alike. Modifications are encouraged, and the internals of Simula are designed specifically to allow for design changes.

The kits including electronics, sensors, motors and all the non-printable parts required for assembly will be available at https://www.chicagorobotics.net.

These parts have been oriented in a way to maximize print quality, so change the "up" direction of the parts at your own risk. Simula uses 3 filament types, Clear/Translucent PLA for the back, Ninjaflex for the treads, and PLA for everything else. ABS can also be used but I think PLA prints look nicer and the brittle nature of PLA makes the bearings work well.

Supports and Rafts are encouraged on all parts except the Ninjaflex treads.

Print one of "Upper" using a translucent filament. My favorite is plain old translucent PLA.

Print two of "Tread" using Ninjaflex or your favorite flexible filament. I've tried a variety of flexible filaments and I find Ninjaflex gives the best results.

Print two of the following:

  • DriveWheel
  • IdlerWheel
  • IdlerBearing
  • HubCap
  • MotorPlate

Print one each of all the rest. I'll be providing detailed instructions on how to set up a quality print using Simplify3D, but feel free to use your slicer of choice!

Notes:

I use Simplify3D extensively on a variety of printers and shortly I'll be providing detailed instructions on how to print Simula for the best results.

I used Autodesk Inventor for the printable parts and Autodesk Eagle for PCB design, and I went through countless iterations to simplify the design and maximize the quality of the finished product. I've tested printing on several different printer types, and I'm looking forward to assisting people interested in getting involved with the project.
